Title: New Study Maps Out America and Canada's Biggest UFO Hot Spots — Washington and Alberta Lead the List
Description:
UNITED STATES & CANADA – A new study has revealed the most active UFO sighting hot spots across North America, identifying where unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) reports are most frequent — and it seems Washington and Alberta are leading the pack, according to data from the National UFO Reporting Center.

The analysis, released by Casino.ca during World Space Week, combined official reporting data with digital media coverage to determine which U.S. states and Canadian provinces have recorded the most UFO sightings per capita since 1974.

The results showed a clear pattern — states with active volcanoes also tend to have more UFO activity.

Meanwhile, the least likely states to spot a UFO were clustered in the South:

In Canada, the province of Alberta emerged as the country's top UFO capital, with one sighting per 568 people.

It was followed by:

However, when it comes to total sightings, Ontario took the lead with 22,860 recorded encounters, far surpassing other provinces. British Columbia, despite ranking third per capita, has logged 7,927 sightings — which researchers noted may be linked to the province's volcanic geography.

By contrast, Newfoundland and Labrador was the least likely province to experience UFO activity, with just one sighting per 7,451 residents.

Researchers and UFO enthusiasts have long noticed that UFO reports cluster near active volcanoes and deep-water regions, leading some to speculate that these areas may act as hiding places or “bases” for unexplained aerial craft.

While the study doesn't claim to prove extraterrestrial activity, it highlights an undeniable trend: the Pacific Northwest remains the epicenter of UFO sightings across North America.

Do you believe volcanoes and oceans hide more than we think? Have you ever spotted a UFO near your area? Share your story at FatCityFeed.com.

Title: She grew up in The Conjuring House. With the help of a ghost hunter, she'll try to save it
Description:
BURRILLVILLE – A movement is underway to save the Conjuring House, which is scheduled to be auctioned on Halloween, including a GoFundMe for people who want to help buy the paranormal attraction.

The movement started with Andrea Perron, who lived in the Round Top Road house as a teenager in the 1970s and wrote about her family's experiences with spirits haunting the centuries-old farmhouse. Her accounts formed the basis of the 2013 movie "The Conjuring," which spawned a cinematic universe.

Title: Scientist Claims Study Found Traces of ‘Alien' DNA in Humans, Suggests Millions May Carry Extraterrestrial Genes
Description:
FLORIDA – A molecular biologist is stirring up global curiosity after claiming to have discovered what could be “alien genes” embedded in human DNA, suggesting that extraterrestrial influences may have shaped parts of humanity's genetic makeup.

Dr. Max Rempel, founder and chief executive of the DNA Resonance Research Foundation, analyzed genetic data from 581 complete families in the 1,000 Genomes Project and found 11 families with “large sequences” of DNA that didn't match either parent.

According to Dr. Rempel, the unusual findings could not be explained by known human gene-editing technologies like CRISPR.

“Humanity may be undergoing genetic transformation,” he told the Daily Mail. “If confirmed, it could be possible to detect which humans carry alien DNA — essentially identifying hybrids.”

In total, his study identified 348 non-parental variants that he says can't be explained by normal heredity or modern genetic manipulation. The research, however, has not been peer-reviewed and remains highly speculative.

Dr. Rempel also analyzed 23andMe data from people who claimed they had been abducted by aliens, and found similar unexplained DNA markers in some of those samples.

However, he cautioned that public DNA databases often contain older data from cultured cells, which can show genomic changes unrelated to extraterrestrial causes.

“We cannot treat these results as proof,” he emphasized, noting that more advanced sequencing such as NGS (Next-Generation Sequencing) or WGS (Whole-Genome Sequencing) would be required for verification.

Dr. Rempel theorized that, if confirmed, alien DNA could eventually explain unusual human abilities, including telepathy or heightened perception. He believes these sequences might represent genetic modifications introduced in ancient or recent history.

Author Nigel Watson, who has written extensively on UFO encounters, told the Daily Mail that verifying such claims would be “as world-shattering as recovering a flying saucer.”

“Should human genetics prove to be influenced by extraterrestrials,” Dr. Rempel added, “we'll need to consider how much alien hybridization is healthy for the planet — and which alien races we might give priority.”

For now, Dr. Rempel says his team needs larger, verified DNA datasets and ethical approval to continue analyzing families who claim extraterrestrial contact.

“Getting that DNA data takes time,” he said, noting that he won't have “conclusive evidence” until the next phase of sequencing is complete.

Do you believe human DNA could hold traces of alien origin? Share your theories and thoughts with us at FatCityFeed.com.

Title: Where in the Universe is it pointless to search for extraterrestrial life?
Description:
The idea that humanity is not special on a cosmic scale has dominated science for centuries. However, a new study challenges this principle and offers an unexpected answer to the question of why we have not yet found brothers in mind. 

Since the time of Nicolaus Copernicus, who removed the Earth from the center of the Universe, science has consistently “downgraded” our role. It turns out that the Sun is just one of billions of stars in the galaxy, and our galaxy is one of billions of similar ones. This trend gave rise to the Copernican Revolution: Earth and humanity do not occupy a privileged place, and life is supposed to be a common phenomenon in space. This logic has focused astrobiologists' attention on red dwarfs — the most common stars around which rocky planets located in “habitable zones” are most often found.

Columbia University professor David Kipping decided to test whether we really are typical. He drew attention to two key facts:

Kipping conducted a Bayesian analysis to assess the probability of our existence. The result is impressive: the odds of us being a typical phenomenon are 1 in 1,600. This is compelling evidence in favor of the uniqueness of humanity.

The analysis points to a possible solution: stars with a mass less than 0.34 solar masses (which is two-thirds of all stars in the Universe, including red dwarfs) are 95% unlikely to give rise to intelligent life.

This is bad news for missions aimed at finding life around red dwarfs such as Proxima b. Although we cannot completely rule out the possibility of life on such planets, priorities have to change.

Future research, such as the planned Habitable Worlds Observatory (HWO), should focus on finding Earth-like planets around stars similar to our Sun. As Kipping concludes, although red dwarfs remain interesting objects, G-type stars should be the primary target in our hope of finding extraterrestrial civilizations.

Earlier, we reported on where extraterrestrial life could find a home in the Solar System.

According to Universe Today

Title: Supernatural Stars Reveal Hot Takes On Controversial Moments & Character Arcs
Description:
Supernatural ended in 2020 after 15 seasons and just as many years, but love for and interest in the show endures, even all these years later. In fact, despite the 20-year gap between Supernatural's debut and the present day, Supernatural conventions, hosted by Creation Entertainment, continue to draw major crowds.

At one such convention, "Creation's The Road So Far... The Road Ahead" in Philadelphia this past weekend, ScreenRant's Liz Declan sat down with multiple stars of the show, including Castiel actor Misha Collins, Bobby Singer actor Jim Beaver, Chuck/God actor Rob Benedict, and Jody Mills actor Kim Rhodes.

Throughout those conversations, the Supernatural cast members discussed several of the show's biggest and, in some cases, most controversial moments, story arcs they would have liked to see, how they felt about changes made to their characters, and much more.

Several Supernatural actors shared their thoughts on their characters' deaths/departures from the show, including some mixed feelings about what those stories entailed.

Jim Beaver spoke about Bobby's controversial death in season 7, episode 10, "Death's Door," which was crushing to many fans. After sustaining a gunshot wound to the head, Bobby is left fighting for his life in the hospital while experiencing a series of memories from throughout his life.

The episode is beautifully shot, written, and acted, but it was still quite a blow to see this beloved character, who had been a true father to Dean and Sam, go. Beaver shared similar sentiments:

"Dramatically, what happened with Bobby in season 7 was gorgeous stuff to play, and it had a huge impact on the audience, and I loved it. I thought it was terrific writing. I thought it was a really interesting thing to do to the boys, to take away this major resource. As an actor, I didn't like it. I mean, I liked the script, but I didn't like dying, and at first, I didn't even realize how semi-permanent it was going to be. I thought, 'Oh, I'll be dead for an episode, and then I'll be back.' That was not. I didn't like that. I did get a lot of really wonderful other acting opportunities because I was suddenly available, but I would have preferred to stick around. I just really loved playing Bobby."

Beaver also shared his perspective on the season 12 introduction of the alternate universe Bobby. Although it was delightful to see Beaver portraying Bobby again, it wasn't the Bobby that fans or the brothers knew and loved. Instead, this Bobby had no connection to Sam and Dean at all.

Beaver reflected on how different that experience was:

"When he did come back with some permanence as the alternate universe version, I was happy to be back on set with all my friends and playing fun stuff, but that Bobby wasn't as much fun to play because he had no relationship with the boys, and the relationship between Bobby and the boys was, for me, the core of what I was doing there in the first place."

However, Beaver also pointed out that the issue was in part a matter of how much time we got with this new version of Bobby, which wasn't actually all that much. Along with a joke about how, for some reason, people believed 15 seasons was enough, he said:

"So, it was a little off-putting to play like I didn't really know them or didn't really care about them, because I wasn't really sure what was left other than just some grouch. Although, I think if the show had stayed on longer, there are more interesting things that could have happened with that guy, and maybe we could have seen a new relationship develop."

Even as his AU self, Bobby remained a beloved character (and Beaver's portrayal was much more than just a grouch), but Beaver's overall comments reflect a desire to have seen more of the original Bobby, from seasons 1 through 7—something many fans have voiced as well.

Other character departures were impacted by forces beyond the writers', or anyone else's, control. This most obviously includes the impact the COVID-19 pandemic had on the Supernatural finale, which saw the death of Dean Winchester before the show's send-off.

While Dean dying wouldn't have changed had COVID not happened, the finale that was planned pre-COVID would have seen the return of numerous characters and therefore a very different ending. Misha Collins explained:

“Plans had been made for the last episode of Supernatural, which was to take place in Dean's version of Heaven, which was a Roadhouse bar, and Sam was going to die, and he was going to come to find Dean's version of Heaven and go into this Roadhouse bar, and we would see all of these sort of fan-favorite cast members, and crew members from Supernatural actually, peppered in as extras filling out this Roadhouse. It was going to be a big venue, so we would see lots of the actors and lots of the characters from the series from over the years hanging out at this bar. Castiel was going to be sitting at the bar, Dean was going to come talk to Castiel, and there was going to be a sort of closure and button on their arc, and the band Kansas was booked to be on stage playing 'Carry On My Wayward Son.' It was going to be kind of an epic scene."

In addition to how thrilling it would have been to see so many fan-favorite faces and get an on-screen rendition of "Carry on My Wayward Son," this original ending would have meant a very different departure for Castiel. Ultimately, Cas didn't appear in the finale at all.

Instead, Castiel's final appearance is in season 15, episode 18, "Despair," when he is claimed by the Empty. Although we eventually get confirmation that Jack has saved Castiel from this fate, we never get a Dean and Castiel reunion or see Castiel on screen again. Regarding that change and his feelings about Castiel's alternate ending, Collins shared:

"COVID hit, and there were all of these restrictions on how many people were allowed to be in a scene at all, and also, it was a two-week quarantine for any actors that were coming into Canada, so they'd have to stay in a hotel room for two weeks, which would have been prohibitive. If you're going to bring 30 or 40 actors up and put them up for two weeks each, it's prohibitively expensive, so they had to jettison that entire script and come up with a totally new end[ing], which was two brothers outside on a bridge. Very different. COVID safety protocols were in play at that point, so yeah, it was very different, and I would have loved to have seen the original ending.”

Like Castiel, Kim Rhodes' character, Sheriff Jody Mills, also appeared on Supernatural through season 15, although Jody had a less ceremonious exit from the show. In fact, Rhodes expressed that she'd been somewhat frustrated with the nature of Jody's final episode:

"At the end, her last episode, there was a whole explanation where she shouldn't go [on an investigation] because what if she gets hurt, that would make Claire sad. ...The idea that, oh, Claire would be sad, didn't sit right with me. Ultimately, I did it, because that's what they wanted me to do, but I did have a couple discussions with the director and was kind of like, 'Um, could she maybe just not roll over quite so fast?'"

Rhodes specifically highlighted the gendered implications of this narrative decision:

"I feel like 'the feels' is often given as an excuse for a woman not to do something, and I don't like to see that. Like, give me a concrete reason; Jody is a concrete person, and this is something we have all agreed is dangerous, and yet we are going to do it to the best of our capability. So, to all of a sudden be like, 'Oh, yeah, sad is a good reason to not,' I was grumpy about that."

Rhodes' point is well-taken, particularly because this did feel a bit incongruent with the Jody audiences had become so familiar with. On the more positive side, Jody survived the show, and it feels safe to assume that she continues to fight the good fight, even after her final appearance.

As mentioned, Castiel's final appearance on Supernatural is in the episode "Despair." This episode, especially the scene in which Dean and Castiel say goodbye, remains one of the most controversial parts of the entire show. In "Despair," Castiel allows himself to be taken by the Empty, but not before telling Dean he loves him (something Dean does not say in return).

This moment sparked intense debate for numerous reasons, although the most notable is tensions surrounding whether this declaration of love by Castiel was romantic. The fanbase continues to be divided on this, although Misha Collins addressed that question head on.

Collins explained:

"I knew that I felt like it was an important, meaningful moment of representation and acknowledgment of homosexuality and this love between Cas and Dean, and I knew that going into the scene, and I was happy that we did it. After the scene fans were not happy with different aspects of it, and there was blowback about not getting adequate acknowledgment or recognition from Dean to what Cas had said and things like that. There was some frustrating stuff to navigate there in the aftermath, but I actually was, personally, really proud of having done that and glad that we did it. And, on balance, I think it's all quite good."

Regarding the idea that some fans still believe this was not a romantic declaration of love from Castiel, Collins said, "I think that is inaccurate." He added, "I know, because I was playing Castiel. So, I can provide the definitive answer."

John Winchester's behavior as a father is one of the most discussed aspects of Supernatural to this day, and because Bobby was essentially Sam and Dean's adoptive father (he even says he adopted two boys at one point), he is often compared with John in a way that heavily favors Bobby.

Specifically, many perceive John Winchester's parenting as neglectful at best, particularly given that he would leave the boys alone when they were young to go out on hunts. By contrast, Supernatural reveals sweeter and sweeter moments between Sam, Dean, and Bobby over the years, including a scene in which Bobby tosses a ball with young Dean.

Because of that, there's plenty of discourse within the fanbase about Bobby being the better father to the boys. When asked what he thought Bobby really felt about John, particularly considering they had been friends, Beaver shared:

"I think he admired him as a hunter, and they were friends, but sometimes your friends just really piss you off, and sometimes they do it consistently enough that you lose respect for them, and I think Bobby was able to see things in the boys, in their needs, in their upbringing, that somebody needed to look out for. And, being as single-minded and as easily distracted by the hunting work as John was, somebody had to step up because otherwise these kids would, you know, if there hadn't been Bobby, what would have happened to these kids?"

Beaver also shared that, in the end, Bobby was proud of his role in Sam and Dean's lives:

"I think Bobby thinks deep down inside, with all his guilt and shame about all kinds of things, I think he thinks he did a good job with them and that they're good strong men in part because of him."

This is certainly a sentiment that many fans share, and episodes like "Death's Door" reinforce just how much Bobby really did love Sam and Dean, even when he tried to maintain a tough exterior.

There were several Supernatural spin-off shows pitched over the years, although none saw nearly the success the original series did. One such show was the spin-off series Wayward Sisters, which would have starred several of Supernatural's most significant female characters, including Jody, Claire, and Donna, and focused on their life hunting together as a found family.

Supernatural even featured a backdoor pilot episode for this spin-off, also titled "Wayward Sisters," which laid the groundwork for the dynamic these characters would have and established what the tone and focus of the show would be. In many ways, it was a new take on the classic Supernatural story. Sadly, however, the show never got off the ground.

Speaking about the CW's decision not to pick up Wayward Sisters and what her feelings are about it now, Kim Rhodes said:

"You know, we podiumed, right? Nobody, I would think, asks someone who won a silver at the Olympics, 'Gosh, didn't you dream of the gold?' Yeah, but we podiumed, and the spin-off was created because of the fans, so the way I look at it now is that the concept and the community was given back to the fans... We get to go where we want to go now, and we are still a tight community."

However, Rhodes also shared that she disagreed with the decision:

"Do I think it was a smart decision on the CW's part? I don't. I still think that it was a bad idea that they didn't pick us up. Do I think we have maintained a presence and a connection with Wayward longer than the show probably would have stayed on the air? Yes, we have."

It's true that Rhodes, and other Wayward Sisters castmates like Briana Buckmaster, who played Donna, maintain a strong bond with the fanbase. That's especially clear during the conventions, at which Rhodes and Buckmaster co-host events like "PJ Party," which Rhodes described as being all about community.

Rob Benedict's Supernatural character, Chuck, undergoes a massive evolution, initially introduced as a bit of an awkward author who is accidentally writing the story of Sam and Dean's life, then revealed to be a prophet, and, eventually, confirmed to be God himself.

Far from a benevolent father, though, this version of God saw Benedict in the role of the show's ultimate villain in season 15. Regarding that major plot twist and his feelings about the change to his character, Benedict explained:

"When I first read the last episode of season 14 when I go bad, I was just bummed. I was like, 'Why am I acting weird?' People may not know this, but I get the script like five days before we shoot. I don't know what's going on. No one says, 'Hey, this is the plan, by the way.' And then I read that episode, I was like, 'What is going on?' And then later, they're like, 'Oh, you're the big bad of the final season.' ...So, that was a big adjustment. I remember thinking, 'Fans are going to hate me,' which is true."

Now, though, Benedict's perspective on this character choice is largely positive:

"Ultimately, I think it's kind of brilliant and I got used to fans saying, 'We hated you in the final season.' Like, yeah, you were supposed to. But the idea that Sam and Dean, their biggest enemy of all, the final chapter in the video game, is to take on God himself. If you can beat that one, then you win, you know? So, I thought that was kind of cool."

Misha Collins had his own arc as God, which likewise saw Castiel transform into a villain, although he didn't see himself as such. On the contrary, Castiel believed that he was going to save everyone by acquiring more and more power and filling the role of the absent God who had seemingly abandoned humans and angels alike.

As with Rob Benedict's Chuck, this was a massive change to Castiel as a character. Yet, Collins felt enthusiastic from the get-go:

"I was excited about it. I mean, that felt really cool, and it was fun to do. It was one of the arcs that I kind of wish we had gotten to play with for longer, and I think is a great example of the adage, 'Absolute power corrupts absolutely.' I think Cas went into that thinking, 'I'm going to do good with this,' and he did not."

Castiel is frankly lovable in all his iterations, although Collins is far from alone in specifically loving the Castiel God arc, which is affectionately referred to as 'Godstiel' by much of the fanbase.

Misha Collins and Rob Benedict ended up loving their villain twists, but there were certain character arcs and narrative choices that weren't as popular for Supernatural's stars.

Benedict shared that he would have loved to see more from the season 11 arc with the Darkness, also called Amara, who was not only God's sister but also effectively the inverse of God/God's light. The Darkness as an antagonist, along with this duality, was fascinating, and Benedict expressed that more could have been done with the story:

"At the end of season 11, after this big, huge buildup of Chuck and God and the Darkness, I wish there had been a little bit more to that reconciliation. It happened super quick."

However, Benedict also understood the rationale behind that choice, saying, "At the end of the day, it's a series about Sam and Dean, so it worked out the way that it needed to work out for that show."

Misha Collins likewise identified some plots he liked less than others for his character. Pertaining to the many different versions of Castiel that Collins played over the years, he said:

"Crazy Cas I could have done without. I didn't want to do more of that. I didn't want to do more Nazi Cas, and, you know, there were some that I was happy to leave behind after a short period, but God Cas, human Cas, and Lucifer Cas were all things that I could have done more of because I had fun with all of them."

Regarding why 'Crazy Cas,' who had suffered as a result of taking on Sam's trauma from Lucifer's cage, specifically wasn't his favorite, Collins explained:

"It just felt like the character never really landed, and it always felt, like, untrue. Sometimes, there were things for me as an actor on Supernatural where scripts would come in, and I would be like, I can't do this and have it feel honest to the character. A lot of the fish out of water stuff, where Castiel was just like not understanding that reference, but we were seven seasons in, and Castiel had been around humans for years and years and years at that point. It was like, he's really still not understanding? Some of the writing I felt didn't really always evolve with the characters, and it felt hard to play those things, and honestly, crazy Cas was one of those things."

Along with Benedict and Collins, Jim Beaver also had certain arcs he would have liked to see explored in more detail. Specifically, Beaver discussed the multiple potential romances for Bobby—including Jody Mills, Mary Winchester, and Ellen Harvelle, among others—none of which played out long-term on the show. Beaver said:

"I would have liked to have seen what happened with that little bit of spark that happened between Bobby and Sheriff Mills because I think Bobby and Jody were a really interesting mix in terms of personality, and I think it would have been real fun to explore what a romance was like in the midst of hunting."

While the cast of Supernatural therefore expressed a range of opinions on character choices, story arcs, and how the show ended, one thing is clear: these actors care about their characters and this show just as deeply as many in the fanbase do.



We want to hear from you! Share your opinions in the thread below and remember to keep it respectful.

Title: Supernatural's Jensen Ackles Threatens Fan in Viral Clip For This Reason
Description:
By
			
			Evolve Editors		


Jensen Ackles poked fun at Amazon Prime Video's The Summer I Turned Pretty during the SPN Philly Con. He attended the annual convention along with his former co-star, Jared Padalecki.

During a fan interaction at the SPN Philly Con on Sunday, October 5, 2025, Jensen Ackles asked one of the fans, “What show are you binging right now?” The Boys actor jokingly added, “If you say The Summer I Turned Pretty, I'm gonna kick you out of this place,” prompting laughter and applause from the audience.

A post shared by Yara – Jensen Stan (@idjit.jensen2.0)

The fan responded by saying, “I don't know what that is.” Ackles, who was surprised by the answer, said, “You don't know what that is? I could hug you [right now].”

The fan further added, “I'm actually making my mom watch Supernatural right now.” Both Ackles and Padalecki appreciated it and said, “Alright, mom. Well done. Thank you.”

The two Supernatural stars attended the SPN Philly Con to celebrate the show's 20th anniversary, which was held between October 3 and October 5, 2025. Also known as Creation Philadelphia, it is an annual convention focused on the popular dark fantasy TV show, Supernatural.

Creation Entertainment organizes the event every year. It brings together many of the show's stars, including Jensen Ackles, Jared Padalecki, Misha Collins, and others. The event features activities, such as Q&A panels, photo sessions, autograph sessions, and concerts.

For the uninitiated, Supernatural is a popular horror drama that aired on TV from 2005 to 2020. The story follows brothers Sam and Dean Winchester as they hunt demons, ghosts, monsters, and other supernatural beings. Raised by their father, John Winchester (played by Jeffrey Dean Morgan), who trained them to fight evil after their mother's mysterious death. After running for 15 successful seasons, the series concluded with a satisfying finale.

Originally reported by Harsha Panduranga on Comingsoon.

Evolve Media is a publisher of leading enthusiast destinations.

Title: Fan who caught Cal Raleigh's 61st home run must have been psychic
Description:
Larry Brown Sports

Brown Bag it, Baby

The Seattle Mariners fan who caught Cal Raleigh's 61st home run of the season must have dreamt of it happening a week prior.

Raleigh belted his first home run of the postseason in the ninth inning to give the Mariners an 8-1 lead over the Detroit Tigers in Game 3 of the ALDS. The two-run shot went into Seattle's bullpen in left-center field at Comerica Park in Detroit, Mich.

In a section full of Tigers fans, a Mariners fan was fortunate enough to get the ball on a bounce. He fittingly wore a shirt that said “DUMP 61 HERE,” which had the FS1 broadcast downright giddy.



The PERFECT person caught that Cal Raleigh homer 😂 #ALDS pic.twitter.com/JcLfXu6vC4

Not only did the fan have the perfect shirt on for the occasion. He also had a wardrobe change ready just in case. After securing Raleigh's 61st home run ball, the fan changed to a shirt that read “DUMP 62 HERE.”



🤣 The "Dump Here" @Mariners fan that caught Cal Raleigh's home run ball REALLY came prepared! pic.twitter.com/ZeZVKmjYRc

The fan named Jameson was even able to meet the “Big Dumper” after the game and got a signed bat to mark the occasion.



DUMP HERE 🤝 pic.twitter.com/Zy8E19UocN

The Mariners held on for an 8-4 victory to take a 2-1 lead in the ALDS against the Tigers.

Jameson's efforts are a reminder to prepare for every day like your dreams are about to come true, or at the very least, have a shirt ready to celebrate the occasion.

Title: Did MAGA Conspiracy Theories Doom the Lab-Grown Burger?
Description:
Ori Toor


Henry CarnellNovember+December 2025 Issue



Scientists once predicted meat-making machines on every kitchen counter, but so far cultured meat—grown from the cells of an animal in a lab or factory—has only been seen at a handful of high-end restaurants. There are entirely practical reasons the stuff has yet to make its debut at McDonald's, but also bizarre, conspiratorial ones; some states have already banned it for reasons that include “global elites” and “bugs.”

First imagined in 19th-century science fiction, cultured meat became a reality in the early 2000s when NASA grew fish tissue in a liquid serum. The first peer-reviewed paper on the topic, in 2005, predicted that cultured meat could address consumer concerns over “nutrition-­related diseases, foodborne illnesses, resource use and pollution,” and the ethical implications of raising animals for meat.

The years that followed brought a mini-boom of research boosted by powerful investors like Bill Gates and Jeff Bezos. But the technology was pricey and the environmental gains didn't pan out. While early ­analyses­ predicted that emissions from meat production could be reduced by up to 96 percent, those estimates were downgraded over the years; one paper even argued the environmental impact of lab-grown beef could be greater than that of cattle.

In 2022, Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene asserted that the government was “surveilling” Americans with meat grown in petri dishes

Farmers didn't take lab-grown meat seriously until about 10 years ago, when farmed animal protein was on the outs because of its association with climate change and heart disease. “Meatless Mondays” were in their Oprah-boosted heyday, plant-based burgers like Impossible and Beyond were exploding in popularity, and the agricultural giant Tyson Foods had invested in lab-grown meat startups and launched its own plant-based products. By 2019, the National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) was lobbying states to pass laws limiting the use of terms like “hot dogs” and “burgers” to the marketing of farmed animal products. You'd have to say veggie “tubes” or “pucks.” (Tofurky sued, and the restrictions were deemed unconstitutional, except when the meat-related words were being used deceptively.)

The next year, Singapore became the first country to approve cultured meat for consumption. The United States followed in 2023, and two companies (including one backed by Gates) brought to market lab-grown chicken products, which are as yet too expensive for most consumers.

In the interim, right-wing trendsetters were busy spreading conspiracy theories about lab-grown meat. In 2022, Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene asserted that the government was “surveilling” Americans with meat grown in petri dishes, and that the deep state would “zap” those who ate a real burger. Though widely mocked, Greene was tapping into a growing political movement that had begun the year before, with influencers going viral for promoting “real”—often raw—meat. The most famous one, Liver King, touted a meat-heavy “ancestral lifestyle” on TikTok that included eating raw organs and questionable “natural” supplements. He later admitted he was also ingesting copious amounts of steroids, but the trend stuck. Proponents, including doctors-turned-influencers, highlighted supposed benefits of animal meat—including increased testosterone and sperm count—and derided people who preferred plant-based options as “soy boys.”

Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who brags of his “caveman”-style carnivore diet, drummed up concern about lab-grown meat when he served as chair of the anti-vaccine nonprofit Children's Health Defense, calling it a ­“catastrophe-in-the-making” and, weirdly, “the death knell to Thomas Jefferson's vision of a democracy.” Soon white supremacists were posting that Gates and other supposed shadowy “globalists” were pushing the government to replace traditional meat with stuff made from bugs. Tucker Carlson seized upon this particular bit of lunacy, devoting an episode of his show to it and declaring, “Eating insects is repulsive and un-American.” One of his guests said the push for bugs was “because they want these farmers' land.”

This was red meat for the MAGA base. In May 2024, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis signed the first statewide lab-meat ban. “Florida is fighting back against the global elite's plan to force the world to eat meat grown in a petri dish or bugs to achieve their authoritarian goals,” he proclaimed. Earlier this year, in the lead-up to ­Nebraska's ban, a state senator warned that cultivated meat would “socially engineer” people away from farmed meat, while Gov. Jim ­Pillen declared it the result of “crazy far-left ideology.”

Despite such rants, the cattle ­industry seems less concerned now than it was a few years ago. The NCBA has reversed course and come out against the state bans, some of which have failed. Trump's FDA recently approved a cultured salmon product from the Bezos-backed company Wildtype.

What's behind the about-face? Politics might be part of it. Fourth-generation Nebraska rancher Dan Morgan recently told the Associated Press that banning meat alternatives seems antithetical to free-­market innovation. “It sounds like a bunch of right-wing Republicans echoing a bunch of left-wing Democrats,” he quipped.

What's more, the whole idea of lab-grown meat appears to give folks the ick: In one 2022 survey, people deemed it “equally or more healthy, but more disgusting than conventional meat products.” As long as prices are high and consumers are weirded out, conventional producers have little to worry about. As the Cattlemen's director of government affairs put it last year, “We're not afraid of competing with these products in the marketplace.”

Title: 'America Must Save Britain': MAGA-Mania and Conspiracy Theories Broadcast Nightly on GB News' New US Show
Description:
Subscriptions

A new daily GB News programme broadcast from Washington features climate denial, vaccine misinformation, and non-stop praise for Donald Trump – as its hosts tell the American audience that the UK needs to be ‘saved' 

Your support matters:

Sign up to emails

Subscribe to Byline Times

SHARE THIS:

Packed with exclusive investigations, analysis, and features

GB News' new US-focused show is providing a regular platform for conspiracy theories – as well as the claim that the UK needs to be ‘saved' by Donald Trump's America.

The Late Show Live launched on 22 September, broadcasting in the US, as well as on the UK channel and on YouTube. 

Speaking at the American party to mark the launch of GB News in the US last month, its co-owner Sir Paul Marshall told the audience of ‘Make America Great Again' allies and supporters: “We need you to come and save us. To rescue us… You are making America great again.”

The right-wing millionaire added: “We need to make Britain great again… We need as many as possible of you… to appear on our channel, to tell the story of what you're doing to turn your country around.” Reform UK Leader Nigel Farage, a GB News presenter, was the headline speaker at the party. 

The new US show appears to be fulfilling Paul Marshall's wishes. 

Hosted by Bev Turner and Ben Leo live from the United States, The Late Show Live is also being shown – along with other GB News output – on Donald Trump's streaming platform Truth+ as well as other pro-Trump networks.

Content from the inaugural US show – which also aired in the UK – included frequent praise for Trump and his MAGA backers by the GB News hosts and guests – and vice versa, praise for GB News by MAGA figures. 

The US launch raises questions about the media and political discourse GB News hopes to frame around the UK, from the perspective of American politics, and the extent to which such a project aims to help Farage's party, which is leading UK polls. 

Both Turner and Leo have rejected man-made climate change, espoused anti-vaccine views, and appeared to cast doubt on the Coronavirus pandemic being real. 

Turner's heavily pro-Trump commentary has previously included her saying “I think we've got such amazingly exciting times ahead” under the President, and on another occasion, “where Trump goes, hopefully the UK will follow”.

Leo also has also praised Trump, called the climate crisis a “climate scam”, and frequently uses far-right tropes about a so-called immigrant “invasion”. 

He has previously referred to pro-immigration politicians as “traitors” and said of the US President: “I think President Trump, in decades to come, will be remembered as one of the greatest US presidents in living history. He has shifted the Overton window on everything from mass deportations, from the trans debate, take your pick… I think his face should be carved into Mount Rushmore.”

The first programme featured an exclusive interview with senior Trump advisor, former Fox News anchor and 2020 election result-denier Kari Lake, who – along with host Ben Leo – repeatedly castigated the UK on issues such as immigration, free speech, and the BBC licence fee, while calling for Reform UK's Leader Nigel Farage to become the next prime minister. 

Subsequent shows cemented GB News' apparent Trumpian worldview.

On its second airing on 23 September, Turner backed Donald Trump's announcement urging pregnant women to stop taking Tylenol – the name for Paracetamol in the US – claiming, without firm evidence, that it caused autism. 

She said: “I just find it astonishing when Wes Streeting comes out as our Health Secretary the morning after and just says this is wrong as though he has evidence… I imagine he hasn't even read their report by the time he went on breakfast telly this morning.”

And she put forward claims that doctors would recommend Paracetamol on the basis that they do not like Donald Trump.

“The trouble is, if people go into the doctors and the doctors hate Donald Trump and they say ‘I'm pregnant, should I take Paracetamol?' The doctors are going to say, yeah, take Paracetamol, don't listen to that Donald Trump”, she claimed.

“Social media is literally awash with people, pregnant women today on TikTok. I mean, it blows my mind, necking Tylenol just to say, you take this Donald Trump as they put Tylenol down their gullet with their pregnant bump. 

She added: “What's wrong with those women? They [have] completely lost their mind. They are that politically enraged by Donald Trump that they would risk the health of their baby rather than listen to people who have their best interests at heart.”

Claims that migration organisations are controlled by ‘Zionist-type people' remain online despite growing complaints

That same night, right-wing American guest and commentator Stephen Kent drew a comparison between diverse London with “Pakistan or India”. 

“The idea that Britain should be British and that, when you go to London, it should feel like the storybooks and the history books that you were promised is not a controversial idea”, he said. “You're not going to London to visit Pakistan or India”.

GB News' Neil Oliver also made an appearance, who has platformed antisemitic conspiracy theories on his YouTube show. His output has largely disappeared from TV broadcasts but he remains a GB News host online, where content is largely un-regulated by Ofcom. 

Kent described climate advocacy as having “religious fundamentalist energy”, suggesting it meant “we need to cleanse the Earth of human beings”.

In the third show, host Bev Turner challenged a guest, Mally Smith, who had said of Trump's attack on Tylenol: “We also should have scepticism if we're taking medical advice from one guy who told us to inject bleach during Covid, which would be President Trump.”

Turner spoke in Trump's defence, saying: “Just to clarify, he was talking about hydroxychloroquine, which, let's face it, sounds like a bleach, which was a medication which we now know did well on Covid.” 

Receive the monthly Byline Times newspaper and help to support fearless, independent journalism that breaks stories, shapes the agenda and holds power to account.

We're not funded by a billionaire oligarch or an offshore hedge-fund. We rely on our readers to fund our journalism. If you like what we do, please subscribe. 

Smith replied: “He did not. He actually said we should inject bleach.”

In April 2020, President Trump said at a press conference, as the first wave of the Coronavirus was taking hold in the US: “I see the disinfectant where it knocks it [Covid] out in a minute. One minute. And is there a way we can do something like that, by injection inside or almost a cleaning? So it'd be interesting to check that.”

On the show's fourth airing, Turner agreed with bringing back the death penalty in the UK, stating that “Britain could lead the way, frankly, in Europe, in bringing it back. And it would dramatically cut crime, I guarantee it”.

She asked a guest: “President Trump's Attorney General, Pam Bondi, has announced that she's seeking to apply the death penalty across the whole of the United States. But with Britain's crime rocketing, is it time to do the same, bring back the death penalty as the ultimate deterrent?”

She also suggested that Charlie Kirk's alleged killer should be killed “by firing squad”. 

There was a flurry of Ofcom complaints after a series of offensive remarks by presenters on the right-wing channel

Turner called the ‘Unite the Kingdom' protest rally in London on 13 September, organised by far-right convicted criminal Stephen Yaxley-Lennon (‘Tommy Robinson') as a “celebration, I would say, of Britishness on the streets of London”. 

The Metropolitan Police described the event as “a very challenging day that saw disorder, violence directed at officers, and 26 officers injured”. There were dozens of arrests for offences including affray, violent disorder, assaults, and criminal damage.

In another segment, right-wing British-Indian activist Aman Bhogal said that the UK Government's plans for digital IDs presented “a very, very slippery socialist slope to full-blooded communism” and that “Starmer might as well rename the country the People's Republic of North London”.

The programmes so far have also seen frequent claims from hosts Turner and Leo that the Prime Minister should replicate Trump's border policy, with Turner declaring to a guest that “we” – either GB News or the UK – “are here to be saved!”

On the programme's fifth airing, host Ben Leo claimed that “there's some streets [in the UK] where they don't speak English at all. I went to one in Leicester the other week.” It is not clear whether he spoke to every single resident on these unspecified streets. 

According to the latest 2021 Census data, more than 91% (52.6 million) of residents in Britain, aged three years and over, had English (and English or Welsh in Wales) as a main language. A further 7.1% (4.1 million) were proficient in English but did not speak it as their main language.

Guest Raheem Kassam also branded the UK civil service's “quote unquote, deep state” as “nefarious” and “entrenched”. 

Exclusive: Analysis reveals surging use of rhetoric about migrants and refugees being of “fighting age”, “scavengers”, “dirty foreigners” and part of an “invasion”, as campaigners warn of channel's radicalising effect

Ben Leo delivered a flurry of extreme comments on the sixth night of the show. 

On Antifa (antifascist activists) being classed by Trump's administration as “domestic terrorists”, he said that “we should do the same in the UK”.

On US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) making light of deportations, he said: “As a Brit who has 50,000 illegal migrants flooding the Channel since Labour took to power, I quite enjoyed that.”

He praised Trump's military deployments to Democrat cities, adding: “I love them. I love seeing the National Guard on the streets of DC. They make me feel safe… I salute them.”

And he suggested bringing in the military against asylum seekers in the UK: “President Trump sends in the military to defend immigration officials in Portland, in Oregon. He's literally sent in the big guns, the army's there, and they're protecting the ICE agents against the lunatics from Antifa. Do we need to do the same thing in the UK?”

On the show's seventh night, Leo cast doubt on Trump's convictions, the pandemic, what he called the “green scam”, and US election results. 

Commenting on the UK Government's plans for digital IDs, he suggested that it was a form of social control, claiming, without evidence, that it could be used to monitor how much meat people eat. 

“Maybe they'd say… you've had too many steaks this year… Your carbon footprint is doing harm to the nation… You are eating chickpeas and gruel for the next six months until your social credit score is big enough”, he claimed.

Leo added: “Call me a conspiracy theorist, but I don't care.” 

The GB News anchor also referred to the Coronavirus as a “so-called pandemic”. 

Commenting on the 2020 US Presidential Election which President Joe Biden won, Leo gave a nod to Donald Trump's debunked claims of election fraud, saying: “Wasn't it interesting that 20 million less [sic] people voted in the election last year than the 2020 election?… Where did 20 million votes go?” The answer is that many Democrats stayed at home. 

In another segment, he said that he was “pro-gun”, adding a usual (and much parodied) pro-gun trope: “I argue guns don't kill people. People kill people.”

While he conceded that it may be preferable to have no guns, he added: “At a time when criminals, bad people, bad hombres, have access to all sorts of weapons, the only sane response can be is: you need to make sure you're armed yourself.”

GB News is broadcast in the UK on streaming channels regulated by broadcast regulator Ofcom, including this new US show which airs on UK television from midnight until 2am every night.  

Asked about the various comments on GB News' US show, as documented in this article, an Ofcom spokesperson told Byline Times: “Our broadcasting rules apply only to content that airs on Ofcom-licensed channels. We enforce these rules fairly and proportionately, acting independently and impartially at all times.” However, this comment came before Byline Times learnt that the show was also broadcast on the channel's UK station.  

“Ofcom has an ongoing duty to be satisfied, as the independent UK broadcasting regulator, that broadcast licensees remain fit and proper to hold their licences. We keep all licensees under review.”

For Richard Wilson, co-founder of Stop Funding Hate campaign group, GB News' “relentless promotion” of Donald Trump's Government “makes a mockery of the channel's claim to be a champion of free speech”.

“Just at the moment that Trump is stepping up his attacks on freedom of expression in the United States, this toxic channel is doubling-down on its effort to ingratiate itself with the MAGA movement – and import the Trump playbook to Britain,” he added.

Polls indicate that around 70% of Brits now have a negative view of America's President – with Wilson saying this shows “how out of touch GB News is with the UK public”.

11 MPs have been paid over £500,000 by the channel over the past year, with £200,000 going to just two Reform Party MPs

The channel's US launch event on 4 September provides insight on its American love-affair.

Politico reported that the US launch party of GB News' new Washington DC bureau featured “many of the Trump administration's biggest hitters” at a private members' club. 

The outlet added that the White House threw its “full weight” behind the launch, “offering up as speakers both Trump's Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt and his Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick” and that “almost a dozen members of Trump's Cabinet were in attendance as speakers discussed a budding transatlantic alliance that could help propel Farage into Downing Street”. 

Perhaps most tellingly, GB News co-owner Sir Paul Marshall – who also owns the Spectator magazine and the UnHerd site — told the crowd: “You are an inspiration. The United States has an incredibly important role to play in the future of Britain. You provide us with hope. You provide us with inspiration. We want to shine a light on what's happening here.”

Marshall was reportedly “close to tears” as he quoted Churchill, branding Trump and his supporters “the new world” which would replace the “old” one. 

“We need you to come and save us”, Politico reported. “To rescue us… You are making America great again. We need to make Britain great again… We need as many as possible of you… to appear on our channel, to tell the story of what you're doing to turn your country around”.

GB News did not respond to Byline Times' request for comment.

Correction: This article initially stated that the US show was not regulated by Ofcom. The show is broadcast on GB News' UK channel from midnight every night. 

While most the rest of the media seems to happy to give the handful of Reform MPs undue prominence, Byline Times is committed to tracking the activities of Nigel Farage's party when actually in power

Got a story? Get in touch in confidence on josiah@bylinetimes.com 



Josiah Mortimer also writes the On the Ground column, exclusive to the print edition of Byline Times. 

So for more from him…

Title: Have you seen Hannah Chacon?
Description:
A 37-year-old woman from Anderson, Hannah Chacon, remains missing after she vanished this past summer. She was last seen on August 9 at 8:30 a.m., leaving her mother's home at Blue Oak Court Apartments on Highway 273.

Hannah has a rare disorder called anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis, also known as “Brain on Fire.” During episodes, she may appear psychotic and experience seizures.

Title: The World's Most Expensive Burger Costs $11,000, Is Only Accessible by Invitation
Description:
The Asador Aupa restaurant in Spain serves the world's most expensive and exclusive burger. It costs $11,000 and can only be experienced by those invited by the restaurant.

Burgers have gotten considerably more expensive in recent years, but they remain among the most affordable food items on restaurant menus. There are a few exceptions, though, the most notable of which recently claimed the title of ‘the world's most expensive burger'. Thought up by the chefs at Asador Aupa, a Basque cuisine eatery located in Cabrera del Mar, Catalonia, this exclusive treat reportedly took eight years of research and experimentation to develop, and its exact ingredients remain a secret. All we know is that the burger's heart-stopping €9,450 ($11,000) price tag isn't linked to gimmicky and meaningless ingredients like edible gold, but to quality ingredients, a unique dining experience, and exclusivity.



Asador Aupa was founded by Bosco Jiménez, better known as BdeVikingo, a Spanish chef and gastronomic influencer known for his love of the Basque cuisine. His concept for the world's most expensive burger was simple – “luxury shouldn't be noisy, it should be unattainable.” Few people can afford to pay $11,000 for a burger, but even having obscene amounts of money isn't enough. To try the world's most expensive burger, you have to be invited by Asador Aupa. 

“This experience is by invitation only. It's not on the menu. Reservations are not possible. Only those selected to experience it are allowed,” the restaurant's website states. “If you think you should be on the list, you can request it and the request will be processed.”



Only those who meet all the requirements are invited to try the world's most exclusive burger, but here's the kicker: no one knows what the requirements are. However, if you do get selected by Asador Aupa, you will be invited to a private room of the restaurant, seated at a table with a few other lucky patrons, and served a delicacy cooked with the “three best meats in the world”, “the most exclusive cheese in Europe”, and a special sauce prepared with a luxury spirit. 

Is the world's most expensive burger worth the €9,450 ($11,000) asking price? According to its creators, “definitely”, but it's hard to say with no ingredients list to analyze. Then there is the fact that you could buy a small car with that money. It makes Golden Boy, the previous world's most expensive burger, seem cheap by comparison.

Title: Musk's X settles ex-Twitter executives' $128 million severance pay lawsuit
Description:
Elon Musk and X Corp have reached a settlement in a lawsuit by four former top executives at Twitter, including former CEO Parag Agrawal, who claim they were not paid $128 million in promised severance pay after Musk acquired the social media company and fired them.

The terms of the settlement, which was first announced in a filing in San Francisco federal court last week, were not disclosed. A federal judge on October 1 pushed back filing deadlines and a hearing in the case so the settlement can be finalized. X in August agreed to settle a separate lawsuit by rank-and-file Twitter employees who lost their jobs during mass layoffs and claimed they were owed $500 million in unpaid severance. The cases are among a series of legal challenges that Musk, the world's richest person, has faced after he acquired Twitter for $44 billion in 2022, cut more than half of its workforce and renamed it X.

X and lawyers for the former Twitter executives did not immediately respond to requests for comment. The plaintiffs are Agrawal; Ned Segal, Twitter's former chief financial officer; Vijaya Gadde, its former chief legal officer; and Sean Edgett, its former general counsel. The former executives say that Musk falsely accused them of misconduct and forced them out of Twitter after they sued him for attempting to renege on his offer to purchase the company.

Musk then denied the executives severance pay they had been promised for years before he acquired Twitter, according to the lawsuit. The plaintiffs say they each are owed one year's salary and hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of stock options.

Musk and X have denied wrongdoing and said the executives were fired over their performance.

Description:

Title: SPEAK UP: Taylor Swift's album, Billboard Live Taipei hit the market (1/2) 泰勒絲新出輯、告示牌新開幕（上）
Description:
A: US singer Taylor Swift finally released her 12th album, titled “The Life of a Showgirl,” on Oct. 3.

B: The pop diva's dominating the Billboard charts once again.

A: Earlier this year, she also successfully bought back the master recordings to her first six albums.

Photo: Liberty Times 照片：自由時報

B: And the good news keeps coming, as she and NFL superstar Travis Kelce announced their engagement not long ago.

A: Wow! It must be her lucky year.

A:  美國歌手泰勒絲10月3日終於推出第12張專輯︰《The Life of a Showgirl》。

B:  流行天后又再次稱霸《告示牌》排行榜。

A:  今年稍早時，她還成功買回了她自己前6張專輯的錄音母帶。

B:  而喜事連連，她和美式足球巨星凱爾西近日宣布他們訂婚了。

A:  哇今年真是她的幸運年！

（By Eddy Chang, Taipei Times／台北時報張迪）





                                                                                A:  Uni-President Department Store's Dream Plaza opened in Taipei this summer. Wanna go shopping over the Moon Festival long weekend?
B:  Wow, yet another shopping mall has opened in Taipei. I haven't even been to LaLaport Nangang that opened in March.
A:  And Far Eastern SOGO's Garden City, better known as Taipei Dome SOGO, will join the department store war once it goes into full operation.
B:   Anything special about this Dream Plaza?
A: It boasts over 100 restaurants, along with the largest Starbucks Coffee in the world. 
A:  統一時代百貨Dream Plaza暑期剛開幕，3天中秋節連假要不要去逛逛？
B:  哇台北又有新商場啦，我連3月新開幕的南港LaLaport都還沒去過。
A:  等到明年遠東Garden City，也就是俗稱的大巨蛋SOGO開幕，這場百貨大戰就熱鬧啦。
B:  這家新開幕的Dream                                    



                                                                                Many people have heard the exaggerated stories of crazed schools of “piranhas” lurking beneath the waters of the Amazon River. Interestingly, it was US President Theodore Roosevelt who helped popularize these tales. He famously called piranhas “the most ferocious fish in the world,” which cemented their fearsome reputation. However, piranhas are not as violent as Roosevelt's account, Hollywood movies, and adventure novels portray them.
  Far from being ruthless killers, piranhas typically feed on worms, insects, small fish, and plants, helping maintain healthy river ecosystems. However, during the dry season, when water levels are low and food is scarce, they                                    



                                                                                A:  Where is Uni-President Department Store's new Dream Plaza?
B:  The shopping mall is at the original site of Eslite Bookstore's former 24-hour Xinyi branch.
A:  Oh, I remember that. Uni-President Group didn't renew the lease when it expired so it could turn the building into a mall.
B:  To continue the literary atmosphere, the Dream Plaza houses the first physical store of Book.com Co.  — with a collection of over 30,000 books.
A:  Great. So book lovers can still visit there as usual.
A:  新開幕的統一時代百貨Dream Plaza在哪裡啊？
B:  就是之前24小時營業的誠品信義書店那一棟。
A:  我想起來了，後來租約到期統一集團不續租誠品，把大樓收回自己開百貨。
B:  為了延續書香，Dream Plaza還開設博客來首間實體店，據說藏書超過3萬冊！
A:  太棒了，愛書人又有好去處啦。
（By Eddy Chang,                                    



                                                                                Continued from yesterday（延續自昨日）
https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/lang
“Piranhas” may make great material for horror and adventure stories, but in reality, they rarely attack humans. While people fear piranhas, it is often humans who pose a greater threat to them through overfishing, pollution, and habitat disruption.
  In many parts of the Amazon, piranhas have long been a common food source and are often grilled or cooked in soup. Their razor-sharp, triangular teeth are also used by locals to make tools for cutting and carving. These teeth are tightly packed, interlock like a saw blade, and are strong enough to remain useful even after the fish

Title: Roy Cooper's Senate race set to become the most expensive in US history
Description:
Roy Cooper is shattering fundraising records to turn the North Carolina seat blue
		

Copy link

facebook

whatsapp

email

Copy link

twitter

facebook

whatsapp

email

Copy link

twitter

facebook

whatsapp

email

Copy link

twitter

facebook

whatsapp

email

Democrats do not have a path to winning back the Senate without taking North Carolina, and they cannot win North Carolina without a massive war chest.

The good news for the party, in both respects, is that the battle for the seat is being fought by Roy Cooper.

Not only has the former governor never lost an election in his almost 40-year political career, but his campaign recently revealed it had broken fundraising records for a Senate race.

Just weeks after he formally began his run before the 2026 mid-terms, Mr Cooper has raised more than $14.5m: the largest ever single-quarter haul for a Senate seat challenger.

There is a reason why Chuck Schumer, the Democratic Senate leader, lobbied for the 68-year-old to return to the political fray after his second term as governor expired last year.

Michael Whatley, the Republican challenger, has been decisively out-raised thus far, and some believe the GOP's only chance to hang onto North Carolina is to saturate the state in outside money.

But barring the intervention of Elon Musk or another big-money Republican donor, the race is Mr Cooper's to lose.

North Carolina Senate races have been shattering records for decades, with some $25m being spent in the bitterly-fought 1984 contest between Jim Hunt and Jesse Helms.

By the time Thom Tillis, who announced earlier this year he would not contest the 2026 midterms after drawing the ire of Donald Trump, won the seat in 2014 and 2020, hundreds of millions of dollars were being thrown at the seat.

Now, a member of Mr Cooper's campaign quoted in Politico believes it could be the first $1bn Senate contest.

The reasons for that are twofold according to R Bruce Thompson, a North Carolina fundraiser who served on Hillary Clinton's finance committee for her presidential run nine years ago.

First, North Carolina is a politically-divided state where contests are closely fought between Republicans and Democrats and often turn on tiny margins.

And second, winning the state opens the door to controlling the Senate.

“These elections become nationalised because of the fact that there is so much riding on them,” Mr Thompson told The Telegraph.

Currently, Republicans have 53 seats in the Senate. Democrats, who have 45 senators plus two independents who caucus with them, would have to flip four seats in next year's mid-terms for a majority.

The electoral battlefield does not look favourable for the Democrats in 2026, but some see a narrow path to winning back the Senate – if they get North Carolina.

The party has had a torrid time since Mr Trump won the presidential election in November, while Republicans won the Senate and kept hold of the House of Representatives. But they have been buoyed by Mr Cooper's campaign launch.

In many ways, the former governor, who began his political career while Ronald Reagan was still in the White House, is a political throwback.

As American politics has become increasingly vicious and personal, he has largely steered clear of the political street-fighting. His genial, soft-spoken demeanour belies his political durability and survival skills.

Carter Wrenn, a veteran Republican operative in the state, sees politicians like Mr Cooper as a dying breed.

“In politics today, you see a lot of strutting, a lot of posturing, a lot of boisterousness, a lot of trying to get attention on social media,” he said.

“Roy Cooper has none of that. He grew up in a small town and he's sort of quiet, got a sense of humour. He's nice to people he doesn't get along with, doesn't agree with, and that's not something you see a lot in politics anymore.”

Mr Cooper is one of the old-school Democrats, Mr Wrenn said: middle of the road, polite, and the opposite of a political showman like Gavin Newsom, the California governor.

When he announced his Senate run in July, Mr Cooper steered clear of personal attacks.

Mr Trump and Mr Whatley did not get mentioned by name, while the lone reference to Republicans was for his work reaching across the aisle as governor to expand Medicaid, the health insurance programme for low-income Americans.

The key message was affordability: reviving the middle-class dream for Americans, stopping mounting federal debt, and blocking attacks on Medicaid and Medicare.

“I never really wanted to go to Washington,” he said. But the odds are Mr Cooper will go to Washington after all.

Of the more than $14.5m he has raised to date, some 90 per cent has come from donations of $100 or less, which his campaign manager says reflects a “massive groundswell of support”.

Mr Whatley, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee who in his time has drummed up hundreds of millions of dollars for candidates, brought in less than half than his rival: $5.8m.

Mr Cooper, whom polling shows has a healthy lead in the contest and high name recognition, has conspicuously avoided naming Mr Whatley, a former backroom fixer who is much less well-known. Occasionally, he refers to him as a “DC insider”.

“Any fundraising on a national level for the Republicans really just rode off the coattails of Trump. That's not hard money to raise,” Mr Thompson said of the former RNC boss.

“When you're running against somebody who has the kind of name recognition and approval that Roy Cooper does, you have to raise a lot. You've got to spend a lot of money to cut into that.”

Mr Whatley's only hope, Mr Thompson believes, is outside money. Super Political Action Committees (Pacs) can spend unlimited amounts on advertising and are much less tightly regulated than direct contributions to candidates.

“Just one billionaire can have an outsized impact on the democratic process,” he said.

The biggest billionaire of them all is Mr Musk, who spent more than a quarter of a billion dollars to back Mr Trump and other Republican candidates in last year's elections.

The Tesla boss, who is projected to become the world's first trillionaire, has recently said he intends to take a step back from politics as his relationship with the president spectacularly, and publicly, fell apart.

But even if the richest man in the world has gone quiet, he has not yet abandoned the Republicans, and will be warily watched by Democrats ahead of the mid-terms.

Filings to the Federal Election Commission from June show he gave $5m apiece to the Republican's Senate Leadership Fund, the Congressional Leadership Fund, and the Trump-supporting Maga Inc Super Pac.

Three days later, he gave $27m to America PAC, which he founded last year. Exactly who directs its day-to-day operations is unclear, but it could be used to support specific Republican candidates.

Political strategists who spoke to The Telegraph expect the North Carolina race to morph into a “brutal” war of attrition. But so far, Mr Cooper's popularity is intact.

“You don't see a lot of figures in politics these days who are popular,” Mr Wrenn said.

“Republicans, if you ask them, ‘Do you like him or dislike him?', most of them are going to say, ‘Oh, I dislike him.' But some are going to say they like him, and Democrats like him.

“Independent voters like him… and they're the ones that really matter in terms of who wins.”

The good news for the Democrats is that, for the first time in what feels like a political age, they finally have what looks like a winning formula.

The bad news is that it takes a popular former governor and hundreds of millions of dollars to get there. Winning another Senate seat, let alone winning enough to take back the Senate, will be more of a challenge.

Title: Trump Calls for Chicago Mayor, Illinois Governor to Be Put “in Jail”
Description:
Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker responded by saying that Trump is "on the path to full-blown authoritarianism."

Truthout is a vital news source and a living history of political struggle. If you think our work is valuable, support us with a donation of any size.

On Wednesday morning, President Donald Trump posted on Truth Social that he wanted two of his Democratic political rivals to be imprisoned.

Trump has been at odds with Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson and Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker, both of whom have opposed the president's plan to increase Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) raids in Chicago and deploy the National Guard there.

The city of Chicago and the state of Illinois have filed a lawsuit to block the deployment of the National Guard. Although a federal judge refused to take immediate action, a hearing on the matter is scheduled for Thursday, with a decision likely to come later this week or early next. 

Trump suggested in his post that the mayor and the governor should be punished for not cooperating with his plan to militarize the nation's third-largest city.

“Chicago Mayor should be in jail for failing to protect Ice Officers! Governor Pritzker also!” Trump wrote.

The statement is indicative of Trump's growing authoritarian zeal since reentering the White House. He has, for example, said he is considering invoking the Insurrection Act to send U.S. military troops to Democratic-run cities across the country. His administration has also (perhaps illegally) used government resources — including workers' emails and federal websites — to blame Democrats for the current government shutdown. 

Trump has relentlessly attacked Democrats in general, sharing a meme last week, for instance, that referred to the Democratic party as the party of “hate, evil and Satan.” He has also threatened to use military force to quell protests of his policies, describing protesters as “terrorists” and people with leftist views as “the enemy from within.”

Both Pritzker and Johnson have responded to Trump's post.

“This is not the first time Trump has tried to have a Black man unjustly arrested,” Johnson wrote on X. “I'm not going anywhere.”

“I will not back down,” Pritzker said in his response. “Trump is now calling for the arrest of elected representatives checking his power. What else is left on the path to full-blown authoritarianism?”

According to independent monitors, Trump's descent into authoritarianism has indeed escalated in recent months. Protect Democracy, a nonprofit that describes itself as an “anti-authoritarianism group,” surveys around 1,000 scholars daily on their views regarding freedom levels in several countries, including the U.S. According to their most recent calculation, the U.S. is currently at a 3.3 rating on a scale of 5, placing the country at a “severe threat” status.

The threat of authoritarianism has more than doubled since March, an examination of Protect Democracy's scoring on Wednesday showed. 

New polling of U.S. voters shows that most side with Pritzker, Johnson and other leaders opposed to Trump's militarization of large cities. According to an Economist/YouGov poll published this week, only 37 percent of Americans are in favor of Trump deploying the military to U.S. cities, while 52 percent are opposed.

As we rise to meet the current wave of authoritarianism, Truthout appeals for your support.

Independent media is a pillar of democracy and a powerful force for justice. Please make a tax-deductible one-time or monthly donation to Truthout if you can.



Chris Walker is a news writer at Truthout, and is based out of Madison, Wisconsin. Focusing on both national and local topics since the early 2000s, he has produced thousands of articles analyzing the issues of the day and their impact on the American people. He can be found on most social media platforms under the handle @thatchriswalker.


Get the news you want, delivered to your inbox every day.


As Trump and his sycophants work to silence political dissent, independent media is a key part of the resistance. Join our collective fight by making a one-time or monthly donation to Truthout today.

Title: James Comey Pleads Not Guilty to Federal Charges
Description: Comey, 64, dressed in a dark suit and red tie, sat quietly at the defense table throughout the proceeding. His attorney, Patrick Fitzgerald, requested a jury trial.

Title: Israel assesses Hamas may not be able to return all remaining dead hostages, sources say
Description:
Israel assesses that Hamas may not be able to find and return all the remaining dead hostages in Gaza, according to three Israeli sources, a fact that may complicate efforts to reach a deal to end the war.
    


            Sources say the Israeli government is aware that Hamas may not know the location of, or is unable to retrieve, the remains of some of the 28 remaining deceased hostages. According to one source, the number is between seven and nine, another source put it between 10 and 15.
    


            One of the sources said the assessments are based on Israeli intelligence reports, as well as messaging from Hamas and mediators in recurring rounds of negotiations. The reason for the difference in the two assessments was not clear.
    


            There are 20 hostages who are believed to be alive, with grave concerns for the well-being of two of them.
    


            During the latest negotiations for a hostage and ceasefire deal in Sharm El-Sheikh, Egypt, Israel has demanded the return of all the hostages – both living and dead – as a condition for ending the war.
    


            The three Israeli sources say Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his cabinet have known for months that Hamas does not know the whereabouts of some of the deceased hostages and may therefore be unable to meet that demand.  CNN has asked the Israeli government for comment.
    


            The United States has also known about the issue for some time, with negotiators in the Biden administration aware that some hostages were held by factions in Gaza over which Hamas does not exert full control.
    


            Barbara Leaf, Assistant Secretary of State for Middle Eastern Affairs under President Joe Biden, told CNN: “It's been the case from the outset that they (Hamas) have not had control over all of the hostages.” Leaf said recovering the remains of some of the dead hostages could be difficult. “It's far more likely they can recover all of the living hostages,” she said.
    


            It is unclear how this uncertainty could affect the current round of crucial talks in Egypt. One Israeli source said that Israel's official position is that Hamas is responsible for all the deceased hostages and the Israeli government expects all of them to be returned. The source said that Hamas might use the uncertainty over its ability to return all the dead hostages to draw out the implementation of any ceasefire arrangements, and to insist that it would not return all remaining hostages until Israel agrees to a full military withdrawal from Gaza.
    


            Another Israeli source expressed concern that Netanyahu might use the uncertainty as a pretext to derail talks. Critics of the Israeli prime minister, including opposition leaders and families of hostages, have repeatedly accused him of deliberately undermining negotiations to end the war, alleging he imposes new conditions for political reasons, particularly when agreements appear close.
    


            However, other sources say that given the heavy American and regional pressure to secure a deal, Netanyahu is more likely to use the issue as leverage over the final details of an agreement, rather than torpedoing the entire framework under US President Donald Trump's 20-point proposal.
    


            The uncertainty about deceased hostages is particularly sensitive in Israeli society, as it resonates with previous unresolved cases of missing soldiers. Lieutenant Hadar Goldin was killed and his body taken by Hamas during the seven-week war in Gaza in 2014. His body has never been handed over, and is now counted among the 48 living and dead hostages Israel demands be returned. Goldin's family has campaigned for years for his return, citing Israel's commitment to the principle of leaving no-one behind in conflict.
    


            Ron Arad, an Israeli Air Force navigator, was captured when his jet was shot down over Lebanon in 1986. Nearly four decades later, his unresolved disappearance remains one of Israel's most painful symbols.
    


            One of Netanyahu's closest confidants, Natan Eshel, wrote a message to a group of journalists last week, referring to the Gaza negotiations and saying “there will be some Ron Arads” – an indication that senior figures in the Israeli political establishment believe that some hostages' bodies will never be returned.
    


  Additional reporting by Tal Shalev.
